user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_lseek:
```c
int32 OS_lseek(osal_id_t filedes, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericSeek_Impl(&token, offset, whence);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_lseek:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_GenericSeek_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, int32 offset, uint32 whence)
{
    int                             where;
    off_t                           os_result;
    int32                           retval;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    switch (whence)
    {
        case OS_SEEK_SET:
            where = SEEK_SET;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_CUR:
            where = SEEK_CUR;
            break;
        case OS_SEEK_END:
            where = SEEK_END;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    os_result = lseek(impl->fd, (off_t)offset, where);
    if (os_result == (off_t)-1)
    {
        if (errno == ESPIPE)
        {
            /*
             * this means the user tried to seek on a pipe, socket,
             * or other fifo-like handle that doesn't support seeking.
             *
             * Use a different error code to differentiate from an
             * error involving a bad whence/offset
             */
            retval = OS_ERR_OPERATION_NOT_SUPPORTED;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * Most likely the "whence" and/or "offset" combo was not valid.
             */
            OS_DEBUG("lseek: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            retval = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * convert value to int32 type for returning to caller.
         * Note that this could potentially overflow an int32
         * for a large file seek.
         */
        retval = (int32)os_result;
    }

    return retval;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions (such as GCC __attribute__ annotations, typeof, statement expressions, nested functions, inline assembly, labels-as-values, or other non-standard keywords) are visible in the provided function bodies and typedefs. All other constructs in the snippets are standard C (function definitions, typedefs based on stdint types, casts, switch/case, calls to lseek/strerror, usage of errno, macros/constants like OS_SUCCESS, and returning values) and therefore do not by themselves indicate a language extension.

The two fragments listed are macro invocations (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and OS_DEBUG). The code as shown does not reveal the macro definitions; macros can expand to compiler-specific extensions (for example: use of GNU statement expressions ({ ... }), __attribute__ annotations, token-pasting tricks that rely on compiler-specific behavior, or GCC/Clang extension handling of variadic macros). Because the visible code uses those macros, their expansions must be inspected to determine whether any compiler-specific language extensions are used. No other lines in the provided code exhibit constructs that would typically be language extensions, so they do not need to be investigated for Rule 1.2 based on the provided material. If further code (macro/inline definitions, header files, or implementation of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET/OS_DEBUG) is provided, those should be checked for explicit use of compiler-documented extensions (e.g. __attribute__, typeof, statement expressions, nested functions, asm, unusual token-pasting, or nonstandard preprocessor behavior).
